thread.title: 'Time was right' to retire: Tony Stewart
thread.title_full: 'Time was right' to retire: Tony Stewart

title: 'Time was right' to retire: Tony Stewart
text:
Report an error TORONTO - 
Tony Stewart is not in the Chase for the NASCAR Sprint Cup Championship this season and hasn’t been in NASCAR’s version of the playoffs since 2012. 
The three-time champion’s woes stem mostly from incidents away from NASCAR like his horrific crash at Southern Iowa Speedway in 2013 where he suffered compound fractures to his right leg in a Sprint car race. 
Then last year there was the tragic accident at Canandaigua Motorsports Park where 20 year-old Kevin Ward Jr. was killed after being struck by Stewart’s car. 
This week Stewart announced that 2016 would be his final NASCAR Sprint Cup season in the No. 14 Stewart Haas Racing Chevrolet. 
Stewart, a sure-fire first ballot Hall of Famer, will leave an incredible mark on stock car racing where, to date, he has 48 Cup wins, 182 top-five finishes and 299 top-10s. 
Stewart was adamant, however, that the decision to leave NASCAR as a driver was his decision alone and had nothing to do with what happened on dirt tracks in Iowa and New York. 
“This was 100% my decision,” he said this week. “There was not one factor that led to this other than just I felt like it was the right time.” 
But don’t expect Stewart to be out of a race car for long. 
He said that he looks forward to getting back to his roots in short-track racing. 
“I’m not retiring from racing, I’m just retiring from the Cup Series,” Stewart said. 
TOP 10 Things to watch for at AA 400 
RAIN ON THE PARADE: Hurricane Joaquin takes a right turn going up the U.S. east coast possibly sparing Dover International Speedway on Sunday from long delay. No lights at Dover so any delay could move race to Monday. 
HAPPY HARVICK: What would make Kevin Harvick and the No. 4 Stewart Haas Racing Chevrolet team really happy would be a in to advance the reigning Sprint Cup champ into the next round of the Chase for the Championship. 
LOSING TRACTION: After a courageous comeback from a broken leg and ankle Kyle Busch raced his way into the Chase but is falling into a familiar pattern of slipping once the final 10 races get underway. He needs a strong finish at Dover. 
SEVENTH HEAVEN?: Jimmie Johnson is a six-time Sprint Cup champion going for his seventh title and he has won at the one-mile Dover oval 10 times, including the spring race this season. 
MUSICAL CHAIRS: Over the next 18 months Clint Bowyer will have been behind the wheel of three different Cup cars. He leaves Michael Waltrip Racing this year to move to HScott Motorsports in 2016 and then takes over Tony Stewart’s No. 14 Chevrolet in 2017. 
HOME COOKING: Martin Truex Jr. hopes he can use his “home track” advantage at Dover to move his No. 78 Chevrolet to the next Chase round. He has top 10 results in the past three races at Dover. 
MOVING ON UP: The No. 31 Chevrolet team of Ryan Newman keeps moving up the standings, in sixth place without a win yet in 2015. He needs just a 16th-place finish at Dover to stay in the Chase. 
FEELING GASSED: Dale Earnhardt Jr. put a big dent in his chances of advancing past Dover when he ran out of gas and finished 25th at New Hampshire in the No. 88 Chevrolet. 
COUSING CARL: There was lots of concern earlier in the season that the No. 19 Toyota of Carl Edwards was off the pace at JGR. Now he sits third in the Chase and will move on after Dover. 
POLE POSITION: By virtue of Friday’s rainout, Matt Kenseth starts on the pole at Dover. He also gets the prized first pit stall and that should give him good track position all race long on Sunday. 
DEAN’S PICKS 
Jimmie Johnson has won more races — 10 — at Dover International Speedway than any other NASCAR Sprint Cup driver in the history of the sport. It’s like Johnson uses Dover as his own private jumping off spot when he is aiming for yet another NASCAR championship. In fact in four of Johnson and the No. 48 Hendrick Motorsports Chevrolet team’s six Sprint Cup championship seasons he has won at the one mile concrete oval they call the Monster Mile. He seems in tune with every bump on the track. The rest of the grid may be bemoaning the lack of practice time this weekend because of rain but all Johnson has to do is look at his notes from the spring race for a winning setup. 
THE BLIND SPOT 
The final 10 races of the season, better known as the Chase for the NASCAR Sprint Cup Championship, don’t leave much room for a Chase outsider to win. On Saturday the best-of-the-rest included the No. 17 Ford of Ricky Stenhouse Jr., who posted a lap of 154.599 mph, good enough for 11th fastest of the final two rain-shortened practices at Dover International Speedway.
